bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, November 13, 1944

div1.p: Hench informs Rojas that his plans for the memorialization of Camp Lazear and the preservation of Building No. 1 are proceeding. He hopes that she will preserve her husband's day book because it constitutes the basic proof for the identification of Camp Lazear and Building No. 1.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Loma viuda de Rojas, November 13, 1944
div1.opener:
Copies sent to Moran
Macia
Ramos
PSH/cb
also sent Hougantes Medico
13 November, 1944
Senora Teresa Loma, Vde de Rojas
207 Calle 17 Vedado, Havana
My dear Senora Rojas:
div1.p:
It has been indeed a long time since I have had the privilege
of either writing to you or hearing from you. I want you to know
that my plans for the memorialization of Camp Lazear and the preser-
vation of Building No. 1 are proceeding, although they have been pro-
ceeding slowly, due to the war. Last week in New York I met Doctor
Domingo Ramos whom you, of course, know. He is cooperating enthusiastic-
ally in this venture. Permit me to send you a carbon copy of a letter
that I have just sent to Mr. Moran and to Mr. Macia. Anything that I
can do, I am most anxious to do.

I have no doubt that you are carefully preserving the day book
of your husband, Doctor Rojas. This is an invaluable souvenir which
must be preserved, as it constitutes the basic proof for the identificat-
ion of Camp Lazear and the little building. I am hoping that perhaps
someday you may contribute this book to the little memorial building
which we expect to erect.

Doctor Ramos has some very interesting plans which he intends
to initiate in the not too distant future, plans which concern the pre-
servation of the little building. I sincerely hope that the hurricane
did not damage it, and in order to preserve it, I am trying to have a
little protective building erected around it.

closer.signed:
PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M. C.
Chief of the Medical Service
